prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Full high-resolution thermal map of Ceres' subsurface - longitude 0
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The observations are divided into three identical SBs, with each of them designed to cover a specific 120 deg longitudinal range. Each SB will last for 3 consecutive hours, imaging Ceres in Band 6. This SB will sample the section from 0 deg W to 120 deg W.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note:
To ensure the observation of Ceres' whole rotational curve, each SB is designed to observe a range of central longitudes for 3 consecutive hours. This SB will sample the section from 0 deg W to 120 deg W. A list of ~ 50 time windows corresponding to this section of the longituds will be provided upon acceptance.
Observations must be performed in October 2015, preferably in the first half of the month (see technical justification)

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: These observations are continuum-only. The TDM correlator mode will be used to maximize sensitivity.

Imaging is key to the project. Observations in the most extended configuration (C36-8) are necessary to obtain a spatial resolution (32 mas) commensurate with albedo features mapping, hence allowing a better comparison with previous HST maps and Dawn data. At the proposed time of observation in October 2015, Ceres' angular diameter is about 0.5", and is not over-resolved by the C36-8 configuration (see Figure 2 in the Scientific Justification), hence allowing one to retrieve its entire thermal emission.
Note that in the ALMA Cycle 3 Technical Handbook, Table 7.1 lists that the largest recoverable angular scale for C36-8 configuration is 0.5", and our simulation also demonstrated that we could recover the full angular scale of Ceres. However, the OT lists the maximum recoverable scale as 0.452", which we consider wrong. We had to fill in 0.45" in the Largest Angular Structure in source box to avoid error message in OT.

Within each SB, the obtained data will be averaged over 5-min intervals. This time interval is not driven by the sensitivity requirement, but by the time it takes for a point near the center of Ceres to move by half the beam size of ~30 km, in order to avoid excessive smearing in the thermal images of Ceres due to its rotation. We will experiment with various integration time in the data processing to find the best value. But for our SNR calculation, we use 5-min integration time here.
In 5 minutes, under typical Band 6 observing conditions, a continuum sensitivity of 60 microJansky per beam can be reached. Based on our imaging simulation, dynamic imaging limitations could result in a moderate increase of the sensitivity (~70 microJansky per beam for a multiscale-cleaned image), which may be alleviated by phase self-calibration. Based on our initial temperature distribution models, given the expected temperature range of 115-226 K over Ceres surface, an SNR over the disk may vary from 80 to 170. This SNR is sufficient to retrieve relative temperature variations of the order of 4 K, which are sufficient to achieve our goals in terms of thermal inertia and emissivity mapping.

The time requested for these observations is not driven by the sensitivity requirement, but by the duration of Ceres rotation of 9.075 hrs. This is quite different from most ALMA observations. For our science goal of determining the thermal inertia of the whole surface of Ceres, we need to measure the temperatures at all observable local solar hours for the entire surface. This requirement dictates that we must sample over the full 360 deg longitudes, i.e., observe it for a full rotational period. We divide the 9 hrs of total observing time into three SBs, with each of them designed to observe a single specific 120 deg longitudinal range over three consecutive hours. The exact time constraints for each SB will be provided upon the acceptance of this proposal.
To maximize sensitivity and spatial resolution, we choose a continuum spectral setup in Band 6 (offering the most extended configuration) centered at 265 GHz.

In October 2015, the phase angle of Ceres increases from 18.7 deg to the maximum of 19.6 deg around October 21 and then decreases to 19.4 deg. Therefore the morning terminator can be imaged throughout the month. On the other hand, the geocentric distance of Ceres will increase from 2.499 AU to 2.915 AU, and the declination of Ceres will change from -31.1 deg to -29.2 deg. The effective beam size at Ceres for configuration C36-8 increases from 53.8 km to 63.1 km. Therefore, while our science goals allow us to observe any time in October, we prefer the first half of the month, from October 1st to 15th, in order to maximize the spatial resolution for a better mapping.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Full high-resolution thermal map of Ceres' subsurface - longitude 120
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The observations are divided into three identical SBs, with each of them designed to cover a specific 120 deg longitudinal range. Each SB will last for 3 consecutive hours, imaging Ceres in Band 6. This SB will sample the section from 120 deg W to 240 deg W.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note:
To ensure the observation of Ceres' whole rotational curve, each SB is designed to observe a range of central longitudes for 3 consecutive hours. This SB will sample the section from 120 deg W to 240 deg W. A list of ~ 50 time windows corresponding to this section of the lightucurve will be provided upon acceptance.
Observations must be performed in October 2015, preferably in the first half of the month (see technical justification)

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Full high-resolution thermal map of Ceres' subsurface - longitude 240
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The observations are divided into three identical SBs, with each of them designed to cover a specific 120 deg longitudinal range. Each SB will last for 3 consecutive hours, imaging Ceres in Band 6. This SB will sample the section from 240 deg W to 0 deg W.

prj:TemporalParameters.prj:note:
To ensure the observation of Ceres' whole rotational curve, each SB is designed to observe a range of central longitudes for 3 consecutive hours. This SB will sample the section from 240 deg W to 0 deg W. A list of ~ 50 time windows corresponding to this section of the lightucurve will be provided upon acceptance.
Observations must be performed in October 2015, preferably in the first half of the month (see technical justification)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Water is one of the most significant and abundant tracers to understanding the solar system, because of its direct connection to astrobiology and sensitivity to probing the physical and chemical state of planetary bodies. Ceres is a large reservoir of water in the inner solar system. The recent discovery of active water outgassing from Ceres, and the arrival of NASAs Dawn spacecraft at Ceres, raise the new urgency to determine the thermal environment and characterizing any subsurface water reservoirs on Ceres. We hereby propose observations of Ceres in October 2015 with the aim of constructing complete spatially resolved thermal maps of the object. These maps will allow us to constrain the subsurface temperatures down to the diurnal thermal depth of a few mm, identify the temperature environment that could possibly host stable underground water ice, and search for excessively high thermal inertia that could be a signature of subsurface water ice. This proposal is the start of a 5-year investigation funded by NASA to observe Ceres with ALMA in a full Ceres-year to constrain its subsurface temperature environment down to 0.5-1 m.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
